With a portfolio featuring leading stocks like Atlassian (TEAM), Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Autodesk (ADSK) as of Jan. 31, $1.1 billion Oppenheimer Discovery Mid Cap Growth Fund (OEGAX) has outperformed both its Morningstar midcap growth peer group and the S&P 500 in all four of the most recent full quarters as well as so far this young year.Fund managers Ronald Zibelli Jr. and Justin Livengood are aiming to keep up that outperformance by surfing for the top growth stocks. "Looking forward, we expect the U.S. economy to expand at a faster than 3% growth rate, faster than the trajectory of the last several years, due to an uplift from a synchronized global recovery," the managers told shareholders in their Q4 commentary.They're betting on companies that they think can maintain above-average earnings growth no matter what the broad market is doing. They're balancing their bets on those companies that they call high quality by emphasizing "risk management through diversification, continuous monitoring and consistent sell discipline," Zibelli and Livengood wrote.Any impact of a possible trade war remains to be seen. But for now, so far, so good. For SVB Financial, much of the Silicon Valley-based bank's loan portfolio has floating rates, so as the Federal Reserve raises short-term rates, SVB's overall net interest margin is poised to increase. On Wednesday, the Fed raised its benchmark rate for the sixth time since December 2015. And the central bank signaled that it might hasten the pace of its rate hikes.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn addition, a large portion of SVB's profit is based on U.S. revenue, which should benefit from the Trump tax reform's lower corporate tax rate.SVB's earnings per share growth has accelerated, increasing  13%, 26%, 30%, 32% and 53% the past five quarters. SVB is the No. 1 stock in IBD's superregional banks industry group thanks to traits such as a projected 67% EPS gain this quarter and a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. Stocks poised to move higher often have a Comp Rating of 95 or higher.Still, SVB entered IBD's Cut List on Thursday after a breakout fizzled.Atlassian, a U.K.-based enterprise software company, is a Leaderboard stock. It specializes in products for collaboration among business teams. Atlassian shows big sales growth in recent quarters, as its top line grew 34%, 36%, 36%, 37%, 42% and 43% vs. year-ago levels. And analysts expect price hikes on Atlassian products.IBD'S TAKE: Atlassion is a former stock on IBD's SwingTrader, an exclusive IBD feature that helps you take advantage of short-term trends by applying the rules of IBD's CAN SLIM Investing System in a swing trading environment. Details on past trades are accessible to SwingTrade subscribers and trialists. Free trials are available.Lululemon is a third Leaderboard stock held by the fund. Sales grew 5%, 13% and 14% in the three most recent quarters, totaling $2.3 billion in fiscal 2017. The company is on track to reach it goal of $4 billion in revenue in 2020, according to IBD's markets team.The company has become an icon of yoga fitness, the area in which it focuses its product line. Q4 results are slated for a March 27 release after the close.Shares of Autodesk, which is yet another IBD Leaderboard stock, gapped up 14.9% on March 7 as the company's move to a cloud-computing subscription model paid off with a better-than-expected 68% fiscal fourth-quarter EPS gain. Also, annualized recurring revenue reached $2.05 billion in the quarter, an increase of 25% year over year.IBD reported that the maker of computer-aided design software got price-target increases from at least seven Wall Street analysts, all of whom rated it as a buy.Among additional holdings, Zoetis (ZTS), a maker of drugs for animals, benefits from a strong companion-animals segment. People are spending more at veterinary clinics on their pets.The farm-animals segment is less growthy but more stable. It does not fluctuate much as the broader economy speeds up and contracts because the cost of vaccines and other health products is small compared with overall costs of running a farm. Also, it's crucial for a farm to maintain the health of its livestock.The company is better focused than rivals that are part of large, more diverse pharmaceutical companies.EPS grew 8%, 25% and 47% the past three quarters.YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:How A Top Oppenheimer Fund Is Coping With Blah GDP GrowthYou Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And Income

Stocks opened in mixed formation Friday as the market sought to recover from tariff-triggered losses on Thursday.Nike (NKE) spearheaded an early advance among blue chips that lifted the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4%. The S&P 500 climbed 0.3% at the starting bell, with Nike and Wynn Resorts (WYNN) among its largest gains. The Nasdaq Composite gave up its brief opening gain and traded down 0.2%, as Apple (AAPL) and three of four FANG stock tech leaders traded lower, and Micron Technology (MU) dived, despite a strong fiscal second-quarter report.The Nasdaq had led Friday's premarket declines as reaction to Thursday's trade news rippled across global stock markets, but Nike traded sharply higher after providing a bullish outlook and positive fiscal third-quarter results late Thursday. A startling jump in February durable goods orders contributed to the gains.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average gave up a brief advance, however, slipping 0.1% below fair value. S&P 500 futures slipped less than 0.1%. Nasdaq 100 futures traded 0.3% below fair value, as Micron Technologies (MU) weighed on early action.A Senate vote early Friday rammed through a $1.3 trillion budget bill, just ahead of midnight deadline Friday, sending the measure to the White House. News reports Friday said President Trump was contemplating a veto of the bill, which covers spending through the end of the 2018 fiscal year, ending in September. Trump reportedly felt the bill failed to address funding for the immigrant population covered under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, as well as for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.The Dow heads into Friday's session down 4% for the week and 9.9% below its Jan. 26 high. That puts the Dow 2.5% above its Feb. 9 low, in what so far has been a moderate consolidation. The S&P 500 is down 3.9% for the week, 8% off its high, and well above its Feb. 9 low.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe Nasdaq has had Facebook (FB) to contend with, and will start Friday with a 4.2% loss for the week. Thursday's move drove the index back below its 50-day moving average, but it remains only 6.2% off its March 13 high and well above the low from its Feb. 9 pullback. Facebook shares were down 0.7% shortly after the open.Friday's economic news showed durable goods orders soaring 3.1% in February, according to the Commerce Department. That was an abrupt reversal of January's 3.5% decline, and nearly double the consensus target for a 1.7% gain. Core capital goods rose 1.8%, up from a 0.4% decline in January, and vs. estimates for a 0.7% gain.February new home sales data are due at 10 a.m. ET. At 1 p.m. ET, Baker Hughes (BHGE) delivers its weekly rig count census.On the Dow, more than two-thirds of the 30 stocks shifted higher. Nike jumped nearly 4% after pounding analysts' revenue and earnings expectations in its fiscal third-quarter report. A statement from Chief Executive Mark Parker said the company sees "a significant reversal of trend in North America," with rising momentum across several of the company's categories. Nike shares dropped almost 3% Thursday, to trade 8% below their Feb. 27 high, and up 12% from a breakout in November.On the Nasdaq, chipmaker Micron Technology fell more than 7% after reporting late Thursday a 213% earnings-per-share gain and a 58% rise in revenue, easily topping analyst targets. The company, considered a chip industry bellwether, sees more than 50% of its revenue from China, putting it at risk of trade retaliation in the brewing U.S.-China tariffs battle. Micron shares ended Thursday 20% above a 48.99 buy point from a March 5 breakout.Grocery chain Kroger (KR) opened up less than 2% after news reports said the company was discussing a possible combination with Target (TGT). Target big-box competitor Walmart (WMT) controls the leading share in the $800 billion U.S. grocery market, which was shaken up last year by Amazon.com's (AMZN) acquisition of Whole Foods.  Kroger shares ended Thursday down 26% from an early February high. Target traded 0.5% higher.Wynn Resorts (WYNN) bolted more than 3% higher after the company announced a pair of unnamed institutional investors would buy the remaining 8 million shares held by founder and former Chief Executive Steve Wynn. Billionaire Wynn, who had been the company's largest shareholder, resigned his executive positions last month amid allegations of sexual misconduct.  Wynn's shares are in a cup-with-handle base with a 192.85 buy point.Global markets responded harshly to the tariffs news, to the White House shake-up and to Thursday's selling in the U.S. In China, the Shanghai Composite drilled down 3.4%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index toppled 2.5%. In Japan, sellers descended on Tokyo's market in a session that left the Nikkei 225 down 4.5% — below its 50-day moving average and at its lowest level since October.In Europe, markets trimmed losses sharply in afternoon trade.  Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris reduced their losses to 0.8%. London's FTSE 100 traded flat.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Stocks Dive But This Gauge Hints At BounceTrump Tariffs On China Slam Stocks: 'The First Of Many'Get Ready To Exit When Leaders CrumbleNot Every Rally Works: Two Red Flags To Watch For

Futures for the S&P 500 index, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq 100 fell Friday morning after President Donald Trump said late Thursday that John Bolton will replace H.R. McMaster as his national security advisor and China laid out its retaliatory measures against U.S. imports. The stock market's major averages plunged more than 2% Thursday on Trump's decision to impose tariffs on $60 billion in Chinese imports, saying it was "the first of many" actions.Meanwhile Micron Technology (MU) and Smart Global Holdings (SGH), two top stocks from the No. 1-rated data storage group, easily beat earnings views and raised guidance in late trading. I am very thankful for the service of General H.R. McMaster who has done an outstanding job & will always remain my friend. There will be an official contact handover on 4/9.— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) March 22, 2018Trump recently tapped to CIA Director Mike Pompeo to replace Rex Tillerson as secretary of state. Both Bolton and Pompeo are hardliners on Iran and opponents of that regime's nuclear deal with the U.S. and other world powers.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. But China could do far more, curbing Boeing (BA) jet purchases, reducing soyabean imports and setting an export duty on Apple (AAPL) iPhones and other tech gear.During Thursday's stock market trading, the Nasdaq composite tumbled 2.4%, joining the S&P 500 index and Dow Jones below the 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 lost 2.5% and the Dow Jones 2.9%, with Boeing losing 5.2%.One positive note: The put/call ratio hit a level typically associated with short-term bottoms, providing some hope that the stock market can get at least a temporary boost.S&P 500 futures fell 0.3% vs. fair value, but that was well off overnight lows. Nasdaq 100 futures lost 0.8%. Dow Jones futures slid 0.3%, even with Nike's 5% early Friday boost.Micron Technology easily beat second-quarter earnings views, with per-share profit surging 313%. Micron also gave strong guidance for the current Q3. But shares fell 6% early Friday.Micron said it will spend to expand memory-chip production capacity in two facilities. The stock, which fell 3.1% to 57.07, also has run up sharply since clearing a 47.08 buy point from a shallow-double bottom on Feb. 26.The relative strength line, which tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, has been hitting record highs. Micron is a member of the Computer-Data Storage group, which is rated No. 1 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.Western Digital (WDC), another big memory-chip maker and data storage group member, fell 1.3% late. Western Digital broke out of its own consolidation earlier this month.Smart Global, which is much smaller than Micron or Western Digital reported earnings of $1.73 a share excluding various items, crushing views for $1.33. Sales of $314 million topped forecasts for $290 million.Smart Global were not yet active Friday morning but rose nearly 10% to 48.41 overnight. During the regular session, Smart Global tumbled 6% to 44.07, but closed above a recent 43.25 buy point.The memory play came public at 24 a share in May 2017.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Stocks Dive But This Gauge Hints At BounceTrump Tariffs On China Slam Stocks: 'The First Of Many'Get Ready To Exit When Leaders CrumbleNot Every Rally Works: Two Red Flags To Watch For

Comcast's (CMCSA) video subscriber losses will more than double in 2018 from last year, says one Wall Street analyst who lowered his price target on the nation's biggest cable TV firm Thursday."We now expect Comcast to lose 400,000 video subscribers in 2018 (previous estimate negative 320,000) while video revenue will fall 1.4%," UBS analyst John Hodulik said in a note to clients. Hodulik lowered his price target to 47 from 49.Comcast lost 150,000 video subscribers last year, even though the cable TV firm expanded the availability of X1 set-top boxes, which provide broader entertainment options.Hodulik also expects video subscriber losses to grow at AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) in 2018.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe UBS analyst forecasts that subscribers to live and on-demand video streaming services will jump 67% in 2018 to 9.2 million, up from 5.5 million last year.Those services include Dish Networks' (DISH) Sling-branded service and AT&T's DirecTV Now as well as streaming services from Amazon.com (AMZN), Hulu and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google.By 2020, Hodulik estimates there will be 15 million subscribers to internet video, roughly 16% of the pay TV market. Cable TV firms aim to offset video losses with higher-priced broadband services.Shares in Comcast tumbled 3.7% to close at 33.23 on the stock market today amid a broad market sell-off. Tech stocks and China-based names led steep early declines on Thursday as an expected  White House trade-policy announcement drove investors into a defensive stance.The Nasdaq Composite and Dow Jones industrial average each opened down 1.3%. China-based NetEase (NTES) posted the worst decline among Nasdaq 100 stocks. Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) took the hardest hits among blue chips.The S&P 500 shed 1.1% in opening trade, with cruise line Carnival (CCL) making the index's strongest move, and drugmaker AbbVie (ABBV) collapsing to the bottom of the list.Some uncertainty left by new Federal Reserve Chief Jerome Powell in his Wednesday press conference, and the last-ditch battle by Republicans to push through a $1.3 trillion spending bill factored into Thursday's premarket session.But markets were most wary of pending news from the Trump administration, as it prepared to possibly unveil Thursday what is expected to be upwards from $30 billion in fresh tariffs on Chinese-made goods. News reports said announcement of the tariffs, which are in addition to those imposed in February against China's steel and aluminum trades, could be delayed, and that the measures would not take effect immediately.China's market dug in for a second day ahead of the expected trade sanctions. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 1.1%. The Shanghai Composite lost 0.5%. In Japan, Tokyo's market reopened from its one-day vernal equinox holiday with the Nikkei 225 jumping 1%.Europe's markets continued to deepen losses as they braced for possible news on tariffs.  In afternoon trade, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris were down more than 1.7% each. London's FTSE 100 was off 1.3%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Facebook (FB) will lose their dominant market share for U.S. digital advertising as Amazon.com (AMZN) and Snap (SNAP) gain ground, according to a research report released Monday.Research firm eMarketer forecasts that Google's share of the U.S. digital ad market in 2018 will slip to 37.2% from 38.6% last year, while Facebook dips to 19.6% from 19.9%.Amazon will grab 2.7% of digital ad spending, up from 2% last year, forecasts eMarketer."Amazon is slowly but surely chipping away at its larger advertising rivals. This year, its U.S. ad revenue will climb 63.5% to surpass $2 billion for the first time," the eMarketer report said.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Google is asking retailers such as Target and Walmart (WMT) to pay a piece of each consumer purchase in return for search listings and links to loyalty programs, Reuters said.Google, meanwhile, has started a new program with online retailers to supplement its advertising revenue with a cut of consumer purchases, Reuters reported.Google slipped 3% to close at 1,100 on the stock market today while Facebook fell 6.8% to 172.56 amid reports that a political advertising firm retained information on millions of Facebook users without their consent.With Monday's loss, Facebook fell below its 50-day moving average. The next episode of President Donald Trump's China trade war has two possible storylines, Beijing signaled on Tuesday. Either the two sides negotiate a truce, or China will match Trump tariffs blow for blow. China stepped up its rhetoric Tuesday, with the Trump administration detailing China tariffs."We will certainly take countermeasures of the same proportion and the same scale, same intensity," Cui Tiankai, China's ambassador to the United States, said in a China Global Television Network interview.Despite the tough talk from China, the stock market staged a modest, up-and-down recovery on Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index both rose more than 1% on the stock market today, while the Nasdaq composite advanced 1%. The Nasdaq led a broad-based sell-off Monday amid growing China trade war concerns and tech-stock weakness, with the S&P 500 undercutting its 200-day moving average.Apple (AAPL), Boeing (BA) and Nike (NKE), all Dow Jones components, are among the companies with the highest dollar-value exposure to China based on total sales. Apple climbed 1% Tuesday. Boeing rose 2.6%. Nike climbed 4%, reclaiming its 50-day line.So far, China's actions have met that standard of matching U.S. tariffs in scale. Over the weekend, Beijing detailed the $3 billion worth of U.S. products that will face tariffs in China. Those products include fresh and dried fruit, wine, pork, and certain steel products.Beijing didn't impose those tariffs in retaliation for the anti-China trade measures Trump announced on March 22, as Wall Street first thought. Rather, China struck a proportional blow against Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs, which largely spared the country.Late Tuesday, the U.S. Trade Representative's office detailed plans for a 25% tariff on some $50 billion in mostly high-tech imports. The duties will fall on lithium batteries, semiconductors, communication satellite technology, as well as some TV components and even flamethrowers"This level is appropriate both in light of the estimated harm to the U.S. economy, and to obtain elimination of China's harmful acts, policies, and practices," the USTR said in a report. The list covers about 1,300 products.The USTR said it was focusing on key technologies that China aims to dominate, while "trying to minimize the effect on U.S. consumers."China was quick to reiterate that it would respond in kind, with countermeasures coming soon.Stock market futures fell slightly late Tuesday.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Is FANG Stock Trade Dead As Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google Lead Tech Weakness?As Stocks Fall Below Would-Be Support Levels, How Low Can They Go?Just Don't Do It: These 6 Top Stocks Teach Key Lesson In Market CorrectionApple Mac Chip Switch's Impact On Intel Overblown, Analysts SayThe Best Growth Stocks To Watch And BuyPfizer Takes On Gilead, Novartis With New Deal In Cancer Drugs

Snap (SNAP) is cutting another set of employees, focusing this time on ad sales personnel, sources said Thursday.The cuts total around 100 workers, according to people familiar with the matter. They represent the final step in a reshuffling set in motion in the fourth quarter, which included trims in engineering and content staff."Late last year we asked senior leaders across Snap to look closely at their teams to ensure they had the right resources and organizations to support their missions,'' Imran Khan, Snap's chief strategy officer, said in a written statement. "Tighter integration and closer collaboration between our teams is a critical component of sustainably growing our business.''Snap, which operates the Snapchat social network app, cut around 120 engineers earlier this month. The company said it wanted to maintain a high technical bar, according to an internal memo distributed at the time.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn January, Snap let about two dozen employees go on the content side of its business. Those moves fueled further uncertainty for staff at a company that's lost key executives and released a widely criticized product redesign.The rolling cuts are in part a response to over-hiring as Snap scrambled to build an advertising business and release new products, aiming to carve out a larger slice of a consumer tech market dominated by Facebook (FB) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google.After Snap's initial public offering a year ago, the company reported three straight quarters of disappointing revenue growth before finally delivering sales that blew past estimates in February.The Venice, Calif.-based company was changing the way its ads were sold, moving to an automated bidding process that allowed more kinds of marketers to participate, but dropped the average price of an ad dramatically.Snap shares slipped 0.5% to 15.87 at the close Thursday.

Baidu's (BIDU) push into artificial intelligence will take time to produce revenue while its iQiyi (IQ) video streaming unit faces challenges turning profitable, says one analyst who initiated coverage on Baidu Thursday."We assign zero value for Baidu's AI business given it is too early for monetization, but view it as a call option for long-term growth," Hans Chung, analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets, said in a note to clients. Chung gave Baidu a sector weight rating.Baidu, China's internet search engine leader, has an artificial intelligence strategy similar to Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Baidu is pushing into artificial intelligence for consumer applications such as self-driving cars. Nvidia (NVDA) and Microsoft (MSFT) are among other top AI stocks to watch.Baidu's iQiyi, a Netflix (NFLX)-like video streaming service, launched its $2.5 billion U.S. initial public offering last week. IQiyi competes with Youku Toudou, owned by Alibaba Group Holding (BABA) and the video streaming service of Tencent Holdings (TCEHY).Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseTencent, Youku and iQiyi have increased spending on content, which has been a drag on profits, says Chung in the report. He says iQiyi's subscriber growth could resemble Netflix's in the U.S."We believe iQiyi could add 25 million to 30 million subscribers annually for the next two years and achieve the scale of 100 million memberships by 2019. Combined with Tencent Video, from which we expect a comparable scale and a 40% overlap of users, this implies an adoption rate similar to Netflix's in North America as of today," Chung said.IQiyi also accounts for about 20% of Baidu's revenue."We believe iQiyi could achieve profitability in the long term given the large opportunity for media consumption in the Chinese market and the company's competitive advantages in content offering and distribution despite strong competition from Tencent and Alibaba," Chung added.Baidu rose 0.6% to close at 225.57 on the stock market today. Baidu is trading below its 50-day-moving average.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:IPO And Top Energy Stock Cactus In Buy Range Amid Higher Oil PricesBest Chinese Stocks To Buy And WatchChart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real OpportunitySell And Take Profits Or Hold? The stock market, small caps in particular, liked the sound of a dovish Federal Reserve policy statement Wednesday. The Russell 2000 was up 0.7% in late trading, outperforming the three major stock indexes by a wide margin.As expected, the Fed lifted the federal funds rate by a quarter-point to a range of 1.50% to 1.75%. The Fed also signaled two more rate hikes in 2018, while maintaining an accommodative monetary stance. Some bankers, including Goldman Sachs (GS), were looking for three more rate hikes this year. The 10-year Treasury was flat at 2.89% after hitting 2.92% earlier in the session.Meanwhile, price action in the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite turned bearish late in the session after CNBC reported that Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said trade policy is a growing concern among Fed members. He also said some asset prices are "elevated," including stocks.The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.4% in volatile trading. Shares of Chevron (CVX) outperformed, rising 2%. In the stock market today, oil and gas stocks outperformed as benchmark crude oil jumped 2.5% to $65.11 a barrel after weekly supply data showed a surprise decline in inventories.The S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq composite added 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Tuesday's levels.FANG names lagged, except for Facebook (FB), which rebounded 1% after plunging 9% in the prior two sessions. The fast-growing oil and gas production firm with a strong presence in the Permian Basin area of West Texas is vying for a breakout from a cup-with-handle base with a 131.68 buy point. The company has delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit sales growth.Floor & Decor (FND) extended gains after Tuesday's powerful breakout over a 48.77 cup-with-handle buy point. Shares were up 3% to 51.20.Elsewhere,  Salesforce.com (CRM) pared early losses but still fell 2% on news it's acquiring fellow enterprise software name MuleSoft (MULE) for $6.5 billion in cash and stock. New highs can leave different footprints, depending on price action, the level of volume, the news and either the lack or the presence of negative reversals.Israel-based Orbotech (ORBK) gapped up more than 9% Monday to a new high and then backed off to a 7% gain in strong volume. KLA-Tencor (KLAC) agreed to buy Orbotech in a $3.4 billion deal. The deal works out to about $69.02 a share in cash and stock.Orbotech closed at 63.99 Monday.The manufacturer of optical inspection control systems broke out March 8, gapping up past  a 57.19 buy point in volume 192% above average. The buy point was not actionable because shares gapped over it. The opening price of 59.58 was the actionable entry.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMonday's action took Orbotech as much as 10% above the 59.58 entry. Strong volume was a bullish sign, but the pullback off the intraday high was not ideal. Given the acquisition, though, it's unrealistic to expect much more out of the stock.Mobile-payments company Square (SQ) advanced almost 2% to a new high in morning trade but then suffered a negative reversal. The stock closed 0.6% lower, to 54.58, in average volume.Square's most recent breakout was from a 47.60 buy point in a third-stage base. As a stock rises, it pauses to consolidate. Breakouts from the first two consolidations are more likely to work than those from later patterns.Despite the late-stage breakout, Square is up about 14% from its buy point.Footwear maker Crocs (CROX) stepped to a new high in volume 30% faster than usual. The small-cap stock rose 1.6% and then gave back part of the gain, ending the day up nearly 1% to 15.01.Crocs peaked in October 2007 and has since suffered two declines and two rebounds, including the current rebound. The stock has been rising since May 2017. It formed a flat base in parts of January and February but unraveled quickly.The once-hot stock has not delivered a double-digit percentage gain in revenue since 2012.RELATED:6 Rules To Help You Avoid A Losing StockSell-Off Is A Lot More Than A Diving FacebookHow To Spot A Stock-Market Storm Early

Stocks opened flat on Wednesday, as Facebook (FB) and American Airlines Group (AAL) weighed on the Nasdaq and with investors remaining cautious as a Federal Reserve rate hike, China trade measures and a congressional budget battle hung over the day's trade.The Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500 each opened down 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average opened to a thing gain, but reversed to narrow losses within minuters of teh starting bell.In a week that has grown increasingly complex, the first order of business for markets is the rate policy decision expected from the Federal Open Market Committee at 2 p.m. ET. This is the committee's first meeting with Jerome Powell as chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Powell plans to hold his first press conference following the policy announcement.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMany federal offices are closed and eastern regional flights canceled due to a wintry storm bearing down on the Northeast. Investors are also keeping a careful eye on the White House's plan to announce trade measures against China on Thursday.In addition, federal lawmakers are once again stumbling toward a last-minute agreement on a $1.3 trillion spending package. A House vote is planned Thursday, followed by Senate approval Friday. The government has until midnight Friday to pass the bill in order to avoid another shutdown.Other economic news includes February existing home sales data from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. The weekly oil inventories report from the Energy Information Administration is scheduled for release at 10:30 a.m. ET, but could be rescheduled due to the storm.Trade on the Dow was tight, with advancers and decliners holding to moves well shy of 1%. Chevron (CVX) and General Electric (GE) vied for the early lead, up 0.4% each. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) dropped to the bottom fo the list, down 0.8%.

Mulesoft (MULE) spiked more than 5%, following a 27% gain on Tuesday, spurred by news that Salesforce.comCRM planned to acquire the enterprise software developer for $6.5 billion. Salesforce.com shares slipped 3.5% at the start of trade. The decline left Salesforce.com 10% above a flat base buy point of 109.29.American Airlines fell 1.6% and United Continental Holdings (UAL) shed 0.8% as the number of flights canceled into New York's JFK and LaGuardia airports, as well as other Northeast cities, rose to a reported 4,400. Delta Air Lines (DAL) and JetBlue (JBLU) each dropped more than 1%. Southwest Airlines (LUV) tumbled 4%.Facebook dropped 2.1% in early trade, as fallout continued over the user data controversy sparked by Cambridge Analytica's use of data during the 2016 U.S. presidential election. News reports Tuesday said the Federal Trade Commission had launched an investigation into whether Facebook's data sharing had violated the terms of a previous consent decree. Facebook sahres were down 11% for the week, below critical levels of support and at their lowest mark since September.Expedia opened down 0.3% after answering questions raised in reports on Tuesday that the company's Orbitz subsidiary suffered a security breach involving 880,000 payment cards. The company said it had identified and fixed the problem, which affected a "legacy platform," and that the current Orbitz.com site "was not in any way involved."Motorhome maker Winnebago (WGO) reversed its early gains and slipped 1% following its fiscal second-quarter results. A 9% per-share earnings gain was a penny short of analyst targets. Revenue increased 26%, well above expectations. The company said tax reforms should benefit earnings by between 10 cents and 12 cents a share this year, with further benefits expected in 2019.Winnebago shares have been looking to retake support at their 10-week moving average, and start up the right side of a three-month consolidation.The IBD Leaderboard line-up showed Tenaris (TS) up 1.2% in premarket trade. The stock has been trading just below a 36.44 buy point in a 14-month, cup-with-handle base.Early action among China-based stocks was mixed. JD.com (JD) pared its early gain to 1.4% and looked to turn around a two-day decline. The stock has traded below its 10-week moving average since early March, working on a new base after a failed breakout attempt in January.Premarket trade on the IBD 50 list showed Illumina perking up 2.5%. The maker of genetic screening and analysis equipment ended Tuesday in a buy range, just above a 249.07 buy point in a seven-week cup base.IBD 50 peer Tal Education (TAL) slipped almost 2% early Wednesday, after gaining almost 6% Tuesday. Shares took a new high and ended almost 14% above a 36.26 buy point in a late-stage cup base.Trade among chip stocks picked up approaching the open. Silicon MotionSIMO, Advanced Micro Devices and IBD 50 name Lam Research (LRCX) rose nearly 2% to lead the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index.Advanced Micro Devices gained 1.6%, after a blog post from the company late Tuesday acknowledged security risks noted in recent news reports. But AMD said it does not expect the weakness to have an actual performance impact on its chips, and that the company would release patches in coming weeks.AMD shares have been struggling through an eight-month downtrend.Cereal maker General Mills (GIS) took one of the morning hardest hits, diving 9% after fiscal third-quarter results narrowly topped expectations, but full-year guidance came in below consensus views.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Stock Bounce Leaves Much To Be DesiredNo. 1-Ranked IPO Stock Breaks Out, Expects Big Q1 Earnings GrowthThese 5 Top Stocks Stood Out MondayThese 3 China Nets Are Flashing This Bullish Signal; This 1 Has Earnings Due

Shares of database software company MongoDB (MDB) jumped Wednesday on an earnings report that came in ahead of expectations and a price-target increase.X MongoDB reported revenue of $45 million, beating the consensus estimate of $42.6 million and up 50% from the year-ago period. Subscription revenue rose 54% to $41.8 million. It reported adjusted earnings of 40 cents, down 9% from the year-ago period but beating the consensus of 43 cents, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan. 31.MongoDB shares surged 7.4% to close at 40.67 on the stock market today. The company, which provides an open-source database platform for businesses, raised $192 million with an initial public offering on Oct 18. Shares priced at 24 and jumped 34% on its first day of trading.Needham analyst Jack Andrews raised his price target on MongoDB to 43, from 34, and maintained a buy rating.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"We continue to view MongoDB as an emerging industry leader with strong products attacking a large market opportunity," Andrews wrote in a research note to clients.For the current quarter, MongoDB estimated revenue in the range of $45.5 million to $46.5 million, above the consensus estimate of $41 million. It projected an adjusted loss for the quarter in the range of 44 cents to 43 cents. The consensus is 43 cents.The company said it added more than 800 new customers in the quarter, bringing the total above 5,700. That compares with 4,900 in the prior quarter and up 78% from the same quarter a year ago.YOU MIGHT ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Spotify IPO Filing Ups Ante In Streaming Music War With Apple, AmazonIPO Breakout Update: This Hot Stock Still A 'Rise,' But Others DiveNew Issues Can Bring Joy, Pain For Stock Investors

Key market index funds sold off across the board as tech heavyweights including Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL) took a drubbing.PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) plunged 2.1%, SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) sank 1.3% and SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) lost 1.4% in the stock market today. Foreign stocks weren't spared: iShares MSCI Emerging Markets (EEM) and iShares MSCI EAFE (EFA) fell 1.1% and 0.8%, respectively.The tech-heavy QQQs gapped down as the FANG stocks and Apple weighed. Facebook tumbled nearly 7% as it gapped down below its 50-day moving average and breached its 200-day line. Weekend reports exposed the social network for insufficient efforts to protect user data amid leaks related to Cambridge Analytica.Apple lost 1.5%, sliding further below a 180.71 cup-with-handle buy point initially cleared last week. The iPhone maker has been developing its own display screens at a secret manufacturing facility in California, according to Bloomberg. That news sent U.S. and Asian display makers down. Universal Display (OLED) plunged 12% to a six-month low. In other news Monday, Nomura Instinet trimmed its 2018 iPhone sales forecast.Among other tech stocks, Alphabet fell 3% to undercut its 50-day line. On the Dow, Microsoft (MSFT) and IBM (IBM) gave up more than 1.8% apiece. The biggest Dow losers were Caterpillar (CAT) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), down more than 2.5% each. Only Boeing (BA), up 0.4%, bucked the selloff.Metals miners, energy and technology were among the biggest sector fund losers. Gold ETFs avoided the decline. Gold futures rose 0.3% to $1,316.70 an ounce.Emerging markets funds have gotten off to a solid start this year, after turning in a strong performance last year.In fact, emerging markets accounted for all but one of the ETFs in the accompanying table. The lone holdout was iShares MSCI Frontier 100 (FM), which invests in countries including Argentina, Vietnam, Kuwait and Morocco. The $765.9 million fund was ninth on the list with a 5.8% year-to-date return through Thursday.EMQQ Emerging Markets Internet & Ecommerce (EMQQ), one of last year's top three foreign stock funds with a 68.4% gain, leads the category. The ETF has returned 11.9% this year, according to Morningstar Direct. That's well ahead of the S&P 500's 3.2% advance.Top 10 holdings as of Thursday included Chinese companies such as Tencent (TCEHY), Alibaba (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU). EMQQ is extended from a rebound off its 50-day moving average. But it is also shaping the right side of a base with a potential buy point at 43.60.Up next is iShares MSCI Brazil Capped (EWZ), with a year to date gain of 10.4%. The $8.8 billion fund tracks the MSCI Brazil 25/50 Index and counts among its  top holdings Itau Unibanco (ITUB), Banco Bradesco (BBD) and Ambev (ABEV). The ETF is testing its 50-day line after a 2% drop on Thursday. If it can find support and make a solid move off the 50-day, that could set up a buy opportunity.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIShares Latin America 40 (ILF) came in third with a 9.6% year to date return. Like EWZ, this fund is seeking support at its 50-day line after a Thursday slide. Brazil accounted for its biggest country weighting, at nearly 60% of assets. Mexico contributed 22%, Chile 11%, Peru 4% and Colombia, less than 2%. The same three Brazilian stocks mentioned above for EWZ are among the $1.8 billion fund's top holdings. Mexico's America Movil and Fomento Economico Mexicano also make the top 10.While most of the funds making the list outperformed the S&P 500 over the past three years, their average annual returns lagged the broader index over the past five years.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Dow Stocks Lead As Walmart, AmEx Rise But GE And Apple Sit OutDow Stays Positive As Stocks Turn Mixed, Bitcoin Tests $8,000These Stock Markets In South Asia Should Be On ETF Investors' Radar

With the market in a confirmed uptrend, your watch list names this week are five hot stocks that are working on bases and nearing buy points: Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Alibaba (BABA), Visa (V), Electronic Arts (EA) and STMicroelectronics (STM). All five have relative strength lines that are all at or near the highs of their consolidations, which is bullish.In addition to the relative strength line, there are many other technical factors to consider before adding a stock to your portfolio, including volume, base structure and base stage. It's important to make note of base stages, because later-stage bases carry greater risk.Alphabet, Alibaba and STMicroelectronics all boast Composite Ratings above 95. The Composite Rating, which runs from 1 to a best-possible 99, combines proprietary ratings on earnings and several other key metrics. All-star winners often have Composite Ratings of at least 95 near the start of their runs.Visa isn't far behind with a 93 Composite Rating. Electronic Arts has an 88 Composite Rating.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseGoogle parent Alphabet is working on a base with a 1,198.10 buy point, and shares are currently trading about 5% below the entry point. While Alphabet's base isn't technically a late-stage one, the stock has surged 95% since an early-stage breakout in 2015. Alphabet could potentially form a handle, with an earlier entry at 1,178.26, but a handle has not yet finished forming.Alphabet shares fell 2.2% soon after the open on the stock market today, undercutting its 50-day line as Facebook (FB) pressured techs early.Chinese internet giant Alibaba is trading 3% below a 206.30 buy point from a consolidation base, with shares getting a boost in heavy volume Thursday on reports that Alibaba is considering a dual listing in China. Alibaba's base is a third-stage base, which is a later-stage base. Breakouts from first- and second-stage bases are more optimal.Alibaba retreated 2.1% early Monday.Visa is working on a second-stage base, and shares are less than 1% below the cup-with-handle buy point of 125.40. If and when Visa shares break out, look for heavy volume as that indicates institutional support.Visa fell 0.4% Monday morning.Visa is one of several payment-related stocks, including Mastercard (MA), Square (SQ), PayPal (PYPL) and PagSeguro (PAGS), that are performing well.Chipmaker STMicroelectronics is trading 3.5% below a 25.40 buy point from a cup base. STMicro lost 0.7% Monday morning.An earlier entry could present itself if a proper handle forms, but one hasn't yet. STMicroelectronics' base is in the first stage, meaning it has greater potential to succeed.Electronic Arts is forming a first-stage base as well in a base-on-base pattern. Electronic Arts shares tried to clear a 131.11 buy point intraday Friday, but hit resistance at that level and turned tail, closing down 0.5% at 128.52.EA slid 1.3% early Monday.YOU MIGHT ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:These 5 Stocks Have Dipped Below Buy Points, But Don't Give Up On ThemFacebook Dives As Data Debacle Highlights 'Systemic' RisksQ1 Earnings: Who Joins Netflix, Twitter On List Of Stocks Expecting 50%-Plus Growth?New To Looking At Base Patterns? How to Count BasesWhy Counting Bases Is A Crucial Skill In Playing Long, Winning Stock Rallies

An advertisement for a gaming app that made a questionable attempt at dark humor backfired on Snap (SNAP) Thursday after pop singer Rihanna shamed the company and caused its shares to plunge.XRihanna, also a songwriter and actress, on Thursday morning slammed Snap's social-media app Snapchat for running an ad that featured Rihanna and singer/songwriter Chris Brown. The ad, which ran earlier this week, was for an app called "Would You Rather," a trivia game where users have to select one of two options.It asked viewers if they would rather "Slap Rihanna" or "Punch Chris Brown." It was a clear reference to the night when Brown physically attacked Rihanna, then his girlfriend, after the Grammys in 2009. Brown served five years of probation as well as community service for the assault.Rihanna responded with a lengthy commentary on a rival social network, Facebook's (FB) Instagram Stories, shaming Snap for approving the ad, for "something that would intentionally bring shame to (domestic violence) victims and made a joke of it!!!," she wrote. "I'd love to call it ignorance, but I know you ain't that dumb."And fans of Rihanna called out the ad for its reference to domestic violence, spreading a fire across social networks.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseSnap shares were down 4.3%, near 17.10 during afternoon trading on the stock market today. Snap shares are down 20% since hitting a 10-month high on Feb. 7, a day when Snap stock bolted 47% after it reported fourth-quarter earnings that smashed revenue estimates and also beat on the bottom line as it added more users than expected.Snap responded to the criticism with another apology, on Thursday."This advertisement is disgusting and never should have appeared on our service. We are so sorry we made the terrible mistake of allowing it through our review process," Snap said in a written statement.Rihanna did not accept the apology."Shame on you," she wrote. "Throw the whole app-oligy (sic) away."Rihanna's response to Snap follows another painful episode three weeks ago when influential Snapchat user Kylie Jenner expressed a strong dislike for a recent redesign of Snapchat, which sent Snap shares down 6%."Sooo does anyone else not open Snapchat anymore? Or is it just me ... ugh this is so sad," Jenner wrote in a tweet. Jenner has 24.5 million followers on Twitter.Snap unveiled the Snapchat redesign in November, intending to make the Snapchat app easier to use and also appeal more to advertisers.YOU MIGHT ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Snap, Twitter Get Price Target Increases As Facebook Overhaul Opens DoorTwitter Borrows A Page From Snapchat To Offer Video PostingSnap Vs. Facebook: Can Snapchat's Parent Zoom Like Zuckerberg?

China will open up its massive electronic-payments market to foreign companies, a move that would pit newcomers against licensed, already established firms in the nation such as Tencent's (TCEHY) WeChat Pay and Alibaba (BABA)-backed Ant Financial's Alipay.XCompanies that apply for a payments license in China will need to store the information they collect within the nation's borders. Those firms will also need to establish a commercial presence in China, payment service facilities and disaster-recovery systems.The decision, the People's Bank of China said on Wednesday, was intended to encourage innovation and competition. But it also comes as President Trump, who has long complained that China has taken advantage of the U.S. on trade, readies a plan to hit the country with at least $30 billion in tariffs.The loosening of the payments market comes after Beijing last year eased rules for foreign banks to do business in China, potentially allowing U.S. giants like JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) to increase their presence in retail banking and financial services.JPMorgan, Bank of America and Wells Fargo (WFC) are also among the more than 30 U.S. banks that are in a consortium for mobile payment service Zelle, which transferred $75 billion through 247 million transactions in 2017.PayPal (PYPL), which owns Venmo, already has ties in China. It has teamed up with Baidu (BIDU), giving Chinese consumers access to merchants worldwide, and has partnered with Alibaba to let PayPal users outside China shop with the e-commerce giant.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn 2015, China said it would let card companies, such as Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA), do business there. But restrictions remain a concern for investors.Meanwhile, Alipay is making more inroads in the U.S. as more Chinese tourists travel abroad, and said earlier this week it will be accepted by 35,000 additional merchants here, joining the 4 million that have already signed up.U.S.-listed shares of Tencent were down 3% in the stock market today. The messaging and gaming company on Wednesday also reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat estimates, although sales missed expectations. Alibaba, which reported earnings last month and has a stake in Ant Financial, lost 1.8%. JPMorgan rose 0.1%, Bank of America dipped 0.3% and PayPal gained 0.2%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:'China's Amazon' JD.com Has These Futuristic Projects In The WorksTop Chinese Online Retailer With Strong Relative Strength Nears Buy PointThis IPO Takes Off As 'Buy Now, Pay Later' Craze Sweeps China

FedEx (FDX) topped fiscal third-quarter views and boosted its earnings outlook late Tuesday, after the shipping giant announced plans to set up shop in more Walmart (WMT) stores as the companies face off against a common rival — Amazon (AMZN).XEstimates: EPS to climb 31% to $3.05 as revenue grows 8% to $16.18 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS of $3.72 on revenue of $16.5 billion. FedEx Ground recorded revenue rose 11% to $5.22 billion, as average daily package volumes grew 6%. FedEx Freight revenue climbed 14% to $1.69 billion, as average daily less-than-truckload shipments increased 6%.Although the key FedEx Express segment saw revenue of $9.37 billion, up 9%, total package volume declined 1%. Lower international domestic and U.S. domestic volumes offset growth in international export package volume, management said.Outlook: Full-year EPS excluding pension accounting and TNT expenses of $15.00-$15.40, above consensus views for $13.51, up from a prior view of $12.70-$13.30. The new full-year outlook implies Q4 EPS of $5.59-$5.99, topping consensus views for $4.74.Chairman and CEO Frederick Smith said FedEx expects strong operating performance in each transportation segment in fiscal Q4."We are increasing our fiscal 2018 earnings outlook due to foreign tax benefits from our international corporate structure, the benefits from U.S. tax reform and improved operating performance," said CFO Alan Graf in a statement. "We remain committed to improving operating income at the FedEx Express segment by $1.2 to $1.5 billion in fiscal 2020 versus fiscal 2017."Stock: FedEx rallied 3.6% late. Shares closed up 1% at 251.99 on the stock market today and are forming a base with a 274.76 buy point, though they have been hitting resistance at their 50-day average and the relative strength line continues to lag. FedEx rival UPS (UPS) rose 0.9% late after finishing down 0.4%.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseNew "FedEx Office" shops will roll out inside 500 Walmart locations nationwide within two years, following a successful pilot program, the companies jointly said Tuesday.The move will add convenience for Walmart customers, allowing them to pack, ship and print where they shop. Customers can also hold their packages at any Walmart-based FedEx Office location for up to five business days, the FedEx statement said.Shares of FedEx and UPS suffered in February following reports that key customer Amazon is set to launch a package delivery service.Meanwhile, the series of package bombs that have detonated around Austin, Texas, in the last few weeks has drawn in FedEx.A package bound for Austin exploded early Tuesday at a FedEx sorting center near San Antonio.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Startups Join Online Grocery Fray As Walmart Hits The StreetsRetail And E-Commerce News And Stocks To WatchUPS Dives Amid Continued Struggles With Holiday Shipping VolumesAmazon Vs. Walmart: Locking Horns In A Battle For Retail's Future

Shares of database software company MongoDB (MDB) jumped Wednesday on an earnings report that came in ahead of expectations and a price-target increase.X MongoDB reported revenue of $45 million, beating the consensus estimate of $42.6 million and up 50% from the year-ago period. Subscription revenue rose 54% to $41.8 million. It reported adjusted earnings of 40 cents, down 9% from the year-ago period but beating the consensus of 43 cents, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan. 31.MongoDB shares surged 7.4% to close at 40.67 on the stock market today. The company, which provides an open-source database platform for businesses, raised $192 million with an initial public offering on Oct 18. Shares priced at 24 and jumped 34% on its first day of trading.Needham analyst Jack Andrews raised his price target on MongoDB to 43, from 34, and maintained a buy rating.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"We continue to view MongoDB as an emerging industry leader with strong products attacking a large market opportunity," Andrews wrote in a research note to clients.For the current quarter, MongoDB estimated revenue in the range of $45.5 million to $46.5 million, above the consensus estimate of $41 million. It projected an adjusted loss for the quarter in the range of 44 cents to 43 cents. The consensus is 43 cents.The company said it added more than 800 new customers in the quarter, bringing the total above 5,700. That compares with 4,900 in the prior quarter and up 78% from the same quarter a year ago.YOU MIGHT ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Spotify IPO Filing Ups Ante In Streaming Music War With Apple, AmazonIPO Breakout Update: This Hot Stock Still A 'Rise,' But Others DiveNew Issues Can Bring Joy, Pain For Stock Investors

Buying and selling tech stocks has proven to be a minefield this week, with Facebook (FB) and Amazon.com (AMZN) among the casualties. But some lesser-known names — including Etsy (ETSY), Pure Storage (PSTG), Smart Global Holdings (SGH) and SS&C Technologies (SSNC) — have climbed up through the debris.All four tech stocks are on Investor's Business Daily's Tech Leaders list, and managed to make sizable gains while much larger companies faltered.One of the most notable is Etsy, which edged up 0.5% to close at 28.06 on the stock market today. But the online retailer of arts and crafts and handmade goods has gained nearly 7% since March 23. Etsy's rollout of new products and website search improvements have boosted gross merchandise volume.Another is Pure Storage, which gained 2.9% to 19.95 on Thursday. With Thursday's gain, Pure Storage is up 5.5% from March 23.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UsePure Storage provides solid-state storage systems for businesses and cloud computing based on flash chip technology. It could get a boost as cloud service provides users with artificial intelligence software, which requires faster data transfer speeds.SS&C Technologies surged 4.1% to 53.64 on Thursday, helping it close out the week with a gain. SS&C provides cloud-based services and software to the global financial services industry. Its software products automate front-office functions such as trading and modeling. SS&C in January agreed to buy DST Systems in a $5.4 billion deal.Finally, Smart Global Holdings rose 0.3% to 49.84 on Thursday, helping it to a net gain of nearly 2% for the week. The company last week reported better-than-expected fiscal second quarter results. The Newark, Calif.-based maker of specialty memory and storage products is getting a boost from its business in Brazil.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Chart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real OpportunityLooking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Stocks leapt out of premarket trading and into early gains Thursday, as the market moved into the final session of the first quarter in a holiday-shortened trading week.The S&P 500, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq Composite all hustled up 0.7% at the starting bell. Boeing (BA) and Amazon.com (AMZN) will be under investors' microscopes Thursday, as Boeing deals with a malware attack and Amazon investors grapple with a barbed early tweet from the White House.Tech stocks were bucking for a rebound on the stock market today. Apple (AAPL) swung up 1%, while Facebook (FB) jumped 1.4%, the strongest early move among FANG stock tech leaders.All three of the major indexes have lost ground in five of the past six sessions. Despite the selling, the Dow Jones industrials and the S&P 500 have continued to find support at their 200-day moving averages.  The Nasdaq ended Wednesday 3% above its 200-day, and 5% below its 50-day line.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThursday's heavy early serving of economic news opened with a dive in weekly first-time unemployment claims, down more than 5% to 215,000 in the week ended March 24, according to the Labor Department. Consensus views estimated an uptick to 228,000 claims.Personal income growth was steady, up 0.4%, in February, the Commerce Department reported. Consumer spending rose 0.2%, equal to January's gain. Core price growth slowed to 0.2%, down from 0.4%. All the February numbers met consensus expectations.The Chicago purchasing managers index is slated for a 9:45 a.m. ET release, followed by the University of Michigan's March Consumer Sentiment Index at 10 a.m. ET. At 1 p.m. ET, BakerHughes (BHGE) reports its weekly rig count survey, and Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker speaks to the New York Association of Business Economics.On the Dow, blue chips moved almost unanimously higher. Boeing stock jumped 1.2%, after the aircraft builder said a malware attack reported late Wednesday would affect neither production nor deliveries. A New York Times report on Wednesday cited an internal memo that said "the attack was 'metastasizing,'" and could potentially "spread to Boeing's production systems and airline software." Boeing shares ended Wednesday down about 14% from a Feb. 28 high, trading just below their 10-week moving average.On IBD's lists of leading growth stocks, Amazon.com had scored strong early gains in premarket trading. But shares reversed and fell 2% at the open. An early tweet from President Trump said of the e-commerce giant: "Unlike others, they pay little or no taxes to state & local governments, use our Postal System as their Delivery Boy (causing tremendous loss to the U.S.), and are putting many thousands of retailers out of business!" An online story published Wednesday said the President "wants to go after Amazon."Amazon, an IBD Leaderboard name, had pared early losses Wednesday to end the session down 4.4% in very heavy trade. The result left it 2% below its 50-day moving average, and about 13% below its high from March 13.Viper Energy Partners (VNOM) surged 2.6%, to the head of the IBD 50 list. The Texas-based oil producer is building the right side of a possible three-month base pattern.Another IBD 50 name, China-based Weibo (WB) climbed 2.4%. The micro-blogging and streaming video site cleared a late-stage cup base in January. It is off its mid-February high, and would need to correct an additional 16% in order to undercut that prior base and reset its base count.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Will Techs Drive Stocks Into Bear Territory?In Market Correction, Look For Stocks Like Lululemon With These 3 TraitsThese 5 Tech Standouts Are Making A Round Trip From BreakoutsDo You Know How To Count Bases And When To Reset The Base Count?Can You Spot The Next Big Stock Market Top? Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in lower than Thursday, not surprising ahead of the long holiday weekend.Top gainers in the Dow included Intel (INTC), Exxon-Mobil (XOM) and Boeing (BA). Inside the Nasdaq 100, Nvidia (NVDA), Lam Research (LRCX) and Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) outperformed with gains of around 4% to 5%.In the stock market today, Facebook (FB) bounced back 4%, but the strength did little to repair damage done to the stock in recent days. Still, Wall Street liked news the company plans to scale back its ad-targeting offerings.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Shares fell sharply in the early going after President Trump tweeted that the online retailer does not pay enough in taxes. But Amazon showed resilience, ending near its session high, up 1%.Netflix (NFLX) reversed higher to just above the 50-day moving average. Shares rose more than 3%.In IPO news, Baidu (BIDU) spinoff iQiyi (IQ) priced last night at 18, right at the midpoint of the proposed range of 17-19. Shares opened at 18.20 but closed at 15.55.Leaderboard name Lululemon Athletica (LULU) followed through after Wednesday's bullish gain on earnings. Lululemon (LULU) shares perked up late Tuesday after the yogawear maker reported earnings and sales that topped analyst estimates.Estimates: Earnings per share to rise 27% to $1.27 on 15% revenue growth to $910 million, per Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales to grow 9.5%, by Consensus Metrix estimates.Results: EPS of $1.33 on net revenue of $928.8 million. Total comparable sales rose 12%, all better than expected.Outlook: For 2018, Lululemon management sees 44-46 cents in per-share profit on $612 million-$617 million, well above views for 40 cents earnings per share and $585 million in sales.Stock: Lululemon shares are up 7% late after falling 2% to close at 78.71 in the stock market today, slightly below their 50-day line after testing support at the key level for several weeks. If the after-hours gain holds, a jump from the 50-day line would refresh the follow-on buy area for the Leaderboard stock.The stock had largely moved sideways for three months after a steep run-up at the end of last year that was sparked by Lululemon earnings in the Q3 report.Nike (NKE), which said it turned the corner in its home market when reporting Q3 earnings last week, still dominates the athletic apparel space and Adidas (ADDYY) is popular with teens and millennials.But Piper Jaffray noted that smaller brands such as Puma, Skechers (SKX) and Lululemon drove category growth in North America in the second half of calendar year 2017."While fashionable athleisure product remains popular, such as lululemon, Adidas, and Nike lifestyle, traditional athletic apparel continues to be pressured as consumers are already well supplied and have moved away from wearing it as casual wear with more comfortable, fashionable options now available," wrote B. Riley's Susan Anderson on March 15, citing the firm's athletic footwear and apparel survey.Lululemon earnings follow the departure of CEO Laurent Potdevin in February, but analysts have affirmed their confidence in the foundation of the company. Potdevin's exit was related to conduct that failed to meet the company's standards, though the cause reportedly involved a relationship with a subordinate and was not related to Lululemon's finances or operations. Chairman Glenn Murphy, a Gap vet, is now in charge until a new CEO is brought on board.IBD'S TAKE: Buying or holding a stock can be risky heading into an earnings report. Here's an earnings options strategy that can help you cash in on post-earnings stock gains, while minimizing the risk from a weak quarter."Reading between the lines, we believe the Board was aggressive and acted on the offense to address any potential questionable conduct issues," wrote Wolfe Research analyst Adrienne Yih on Feb. 6. "We believe lululemon has one of the strongest brands in the activewear space and is not at jeopardy of a potential sales backlash."But Jefferies' Randal Konik said the management turnover "gives (him) some pause," given that Lululemon's creative director, Lee Holman, left at the end of 2017. Konik continues to be cautious of "decelerating athleisure momentum, a margin recovery story where the low hanging fruit has already been picked, and tough compares."Not long after the resignation, Lululemon founder Chip Wilson, often a controversial figure himself, sold off 2.75 million shares for about $211 million, the first time he's shed stock since September 2014, according to Bloomberg. But the sale reportedly was unrelated to Potdevin's exit; Wilson told the outlet that he wanted to fund other business ventures.Long term, RBC Capital Markets' Brian Tunick reaffirmed in January his view that Lululemon is on track for its $4 billion sales target for 2020.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: These 6 Apparel Stocks Are Worth Window-ShoppingAdobe's Top 10 Retail Predictions For 2018Why Finish Line Takeover Is Good For Nike, Bad For Foot LockerWhy Nike Is 'Back In Business' In North America After Sales Slump

Dow Jones futures, S&P 500 index futures and Nasdaq 100 futures turned higher Wednesday morning after the stock market suffered big losses Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite undercut Friday's recent low as Nvidia (NVDA), Tesla (TSLA), Facebook (FB) and Twitter (TWTR) led the tech meltdown. The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones neared their 200-day moving averages again.S&P 500 index futures rose 0.25% vs. fair value. Dow Jones futures advanced nearly 0.3% vs. fair value. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 0.25%.Keep in mind that premarket trading doesn't always translate into how stocks will open and close the following day. Futures looked strong ahead of Tuesday's regular session, but after a modest gain at the open the stock deteriorated.After crashing 8.2% Tuesday on several negative headlines, Tesla stock fell 1.1% early Wednesday after Moody's downgraded it late Tuesday on Model 3 production concerns. Nvidia, Facebook and Twitter rose roughly in the premarket. But during Tuesday's regular session, Nvidia fell 7.8%, Facebook 4.9% and Twitter 12%, all in more than double normal volume. Nvidia and Twitter tumbled through their 50-day moving averages.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseApparel-Shoes & Related Manufacturing, ranked No. 7 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks, edged up 0.1% on Tuesday. That was the only group in the top 50 that managed any gain in the broad stock market sell-off. Dow Jones component Nike (NKE) edged 0.4% higher. Nike's relative strength line, which gauges a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, rose to an 18-month high.Investors should be looking to raise cash by taking profits in winning stocks. Be quick to cut losses. This is not a time to be buying. The stock market is flashing numerous negative signals. In any case, few top stocks are even attempting breakouts.This is a time to be building a watch list, regularly adding and pruning stocks of interest along the way. Don't forget the pruning: These six big-cap tech stocks reclaimed their 50-day lines on Monday, including Nvidia, but sold off Tuesday.When the stock market shows a convincing uptrend once again, the first stocks to break out are often the rally's big winners. So you want to be ready.Reading the Stock Market Today and The Big Picture every day will keep you in sync with the major stock market averages and leading stocks. Investors definitely should read the latest Big Picture.Nike closed just below its 50-day line on Tuesday, continuing to consolidate, but it has not quite formed a proper base. Nike fell 1% in the premarketMeanwhile, yogawear retailer and maker Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and home furnishings chain RH (RH) shot up late on strong earnings. Neither was active early Wednesday yet.Several other apparel and retail stocks are faring well. Five Below (FIVE) once again tried to clear a buy point Tuesday, but reversed. Urban Outfitters (URBN) fell just below a buy point. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Burlington Stores (BURL) are still in range. Macy's (M) and Canada Goose (GOOS) are consolidating bullishly.Keep in mind that these are pockets of resilience. Many other retail stocks, including Walmart (WMT) and Target (TGT), are struggling. And retail may be seen as a quasi-defensive investor play right now. If the stock market rebounds, investors could lose their interest in apparel and retail names and jump back into techs.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Market, Leading Stocks Face New TroublesThese Stocks Got Cut From, Added To IBD Stock Lists After Market DropsThese 6 Apparel Stocks Are Worth Window-ShoppingAdobe's Top 10 Retail Predictions For 2018

Google-parent Alphabet's (GOOGL) investments in Waymo suddenly look much bigger amid its plans to buy as many as 20,000 luxury, autonomous electric cars from Jaguar Land Rover.Waymo and Jaguar plan to move into production with the crossover sport-utility by 2020. The companies made the announcement at the New York Automobile Show on Tuesday. Waymo will utilize Jaguar's I-Pace electric vehicles, the companies said.Alphabet spun off Waymo as a stand-alone company in late 2016. That move gave Alphabet some liability protection as more Waymo autonomous vehicles travel on public roads.Alphabet has been footing the bill for Waymo's purchases of  Fiat Chrysler's (FCAU) Pacifica hybrid minivans, analysts say. Waymo uses some 600 of the hybrid minivans and has ordered "thousands" more for delivery as it expands trials.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"We don't disclose financial details," a Waymo spokesman said in an email. The company was asked about terms of the Jaguar deal.On top of the basic price of vehicles, autonomous technology currently can add $100,000 or more to the vehicle cost depending on how many laser systems, radar, cameras and redundant computers are used. Waymo, though, has been driving down the cost of laser systems and other autonomous technology.Waymo's driverless Chrysler Pacifica minivans have logged over 5 million miles in parts of 25 cities. Waymo aims to be first to market with a commercial robo-taxi service in Phoenix.Aside from car manufacturing partners, Waymo has lined up Avis Budget Group (CAR) and AutoNation (AN) for servicing and housing its fleet.Rival General Motors (GM), which plans to launch a robo-taxi service in an unidentified "dense, urban" setting in 2019, uses laser systems and has been testing Chevrolet Bolt electric cars in San Francisco.Companies racing to build autonomous vehicles —  including Waymo, GM, Tesla (TSLA), Aptiv (APTV), Ford (F) and Daimler — will face even more scrutiny in the wake of a fatal accident involving an Uber vehicle last week in Tempe, Ariz.Alphabet stock fell 4.5% to 1,006.94 on the stock market today amid a broad sell-off in technology stocks. Shares are now trading about 17% below a technical buy point of 1,208. The company has been pressured over worries of increased regulation in the wake of Facebook's (FB) data privacy problems.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Chart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real OpportunityLooking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? In the largest initial public offering of a China company since the debut of Alibaba (BABA) in 2014, Beijing-based iQiyi (IQ) is set to begin trading Thursday.Spun off by China-based Baidu (BIDU) and considered the Netflix (NFLX) of China, iQiyi looks to raise $2.3 billion by offering 125 million shares at a price range of 17-19. That would provide a fully diluted market value of $13.7 billion.The company accounts for roughly 20% of Baidu's revenue. Baidu currently holds a 69.6% stake in the company and will remain as a majority shareholder post-IPO.Shares should price late Wednesday and begin trading Thursday on the Nasdaq under the ticker IQ. The lead underwriters are Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWith 50 million subscribers, iQiyi has roughly a 28% market share in China.Rivals Alibaba (BABA) and Tencent (TCEHY) have their own streaming services in a hotly contested battle for viewers. Alibaba was the largest IPO of a China-based company on a U.S. exchange, raising $25 billion.IPO research and advisory firm IPOboutique.com issued a cautionary report on iQiyi Wednesday. On the plus side, it said, channel checks suggest the request for shares is strong, with the IPO being "many multiple-times oversubscribed," according to underwriter guidance.But the performance of other recent China IPOs "does not provide any boost of confidence for IPOs coming from China," the research firm said. Among these IPOs is Bilibili (BILI), which began trading on the Nasdaq on Wednesday.Bilibili provides an online entertainment platform serving young generations in China with 72 million monthly visitors. The company raised $483 million by offering 42 million shares at 11.50, within the range of 10.50 to 12.50. Shares fell to 9.62 and closed at 11.24.Another is China-based OneSmart International Education Group (ONE), which also began trading Wednesday. OneSmart raised $179 million, pricing 16.3 million American Depositary Shares at 11, the low end of its range. Futures for the S&P 500 index, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq 100 were little changed Wednesday morning ahead of an expected Fed rate hike this afternoon.The Dow Jones led a lackluster stock market rebound Tuesday following the Facebook (FB)-led sell-off  Monday, even as Facebook continued to slump. IBD 50 stocks Applied Materials (AMAT) and Lam Research (LRCX) reclaimed buy points Tuesday, joining fellow chip gear leaders ASML Holding (ASML) and Teradyne (TER). So did Dow Jones futures. Nasdaq 100 futures sank 0.25%, with Facebook sliding again.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Smart Global vaulted 6.2% to 44.92, moving back above a 43.25 buy point and rising to the top of the 5% chase zone.Facebook has fallen more than 9% already this week, plunging through key support. It's a major component of the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 index. Also, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Twitter (TWTR) and Snap (SNAP) also fell at least in part in sympathy. But so far, despite Monday's sell-off in the major averages and Tuesday's tepid bounce, leading stocks haven't suffered too much damage.Not every stock market rally needs semiconductors playing a big role.
